N0 224Berne, le 11 juin 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,En response a la note que vous avez bien voulu adresser au Gouvernement Federal d'Autriche sous le N0 21/31/27 en date du 8 mars a. cte. au sujet de la suite que ce Gouvernement se propose de donner au vceu de PAssemblee a l'egard de la limitation des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes pendant les deux annees fiscales qui suivront le prochain exercice budgetaire, mon Gouvernement me charge de vous prier de bien vouloir porter a la connais-sance du Conseil que le vceu de PAssemblee, cite ci-haut, ne saurait se rap-jorter a PAutriche dont la situation militaire, navale et aerienne est fixee par es dispositions y relatives du Traite" de Saint-Germain du 10 septembre 1920.Veuillez agreer, etc.(Signe) E. Delegacion de Chilea lasociedad de las naciones.Paris, le 10 juin. 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,Par lettre en date du 8 mars 1921, vous avez bien voulu, conformement a la decision prise par le Conseil de la Societe des Nations, transmettre a notre Gouvernement le vceu adopte le 14 decembre 1920 par la majorite de PAssemblee de la Societe des Nations, au sujet de la limitation des depenses militaires, navales et aeriennes, pendant les deux annees fiscales suivant le prochain exercice budgetaire.Au nom du Gouvernement chilien, nous avons 1'honneur de vous declarer qu'il n'entre pas dans les intentions du Gouvernement de la Republique de faire des augmentations dans les depenses militaires et navales, pendant les deux prochaines annees, etant cependant entendu que cela n'implique aucunement de sa part un engagement en 1'espece.Veuillez agreer, Monsieur le Secretaire General, les assurances de notre haute et distinguee consideration.(Signe) AGUSTIN EDWARDS.MANUEL RIVAS VICUNA.Sir Eric Drummond,Secretaire General de la Societe des Nations, Geneve. REPLY OF THE AUSTRIAN GOVERNMENT.[Translation,]From the Representative of the Federal Government of Austria with the Secretariat of the League of Nations.No. 224. Berne, June 11th, 1921.Sir,In reply to your letter No. 21/31/27, dated March 8th, to the Federal Government of Austria, with regard to the action that that Government pro-poses to take as a result of the recommendations of the Assembly with regard to limitation of military, naval and air expenditure during the two financial years following the next Budget, my Government instructs me to beg you to be so good as to inform the Council that the above-mentioned recommendation of the Assembly does not apply to Austria, whose military, naval and air establishment is fixed by the provisions referring thereto in the Treaty of St. Germain of September 10th, 1920.I have the honour to be, etc.(Signed) E. PFLUGL.The Hon. Sir Eric Drummond, C.B., K.C.M.G., Secretary-General of the League of Nations, Geneva.REPLY OF THE CHILIAN GOVERNMENT.[Translation.]Chilian Delegation to the League of Nations.Paris, June 10th, 1921.Sir,In your letter of March 8th, 1921, you were good enough, acting in conformity with the decision taken by the Council of the League of Nations, to transmit to our Government the Resolution which was adopted on December 14th, 1920, by a majority of the Assembly of the League of Nations, in regard to the limitation of military, naval and air expenditure during the two financial years following the next financial year.We are directed by the Chilian Government to inform you, on its behalf, that it does not propose to make any increase in military and naval expen-diture during the next two years, it being, however, understood that this statement is not to be regarded in any sense as a formal undertaking on its part.I have the honour to be, etc.(Signed) AGUSTIN EDWARDS. To Sir Eric Drummond, MANUEL RIVAS VICUNA.Secretary-General, League of Nations. Geneve, le 27 juin 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,En reponse a votre lettre du 8 mars 1921 (21/31/27), relative a la limitation des depenses militaires, j'ai 1'honneur de vous faire savoir, d'ordre de mon Gouvernement, que, malgre son vif desir de contribuer a la reduction graduelle des armements, il lui est impossible de se conformer pour le moment au vceu adopte par PAssemblee de la Societe des Nations, dans sa seance du 14 decembre 1920, et de s'occuper de cette question, cela vu Petat de guerre existant actuellement avec la Turquie, etat de guerre dont la responsabilite n'incombe certainement pas a la Grece.Veuillez agreer, etc.(Signe) V. DENDRAMIS, Directeur du Secretariat hellenique permanent.A PHonorable Sir Eric Drummond,Secretaire General de la Societe des Nations, Geneve. 4\REPLY OF THE SPANISH GOVERNMENT.[Translation.]Ministry of State League of Nations Section of the Spanish Foreign Office.Madrid, May mh, 1921.Sir,In reply to your communication of March 8th, I have the honour to inform you as follows :The Spanish Government, in conformity with its traditions and its character, is inclined to give favourable consideration to any proposal which aims at achieving a reduction of military expenditure by means of a unanimous agreement between all States.Nevertheless, as was indicated in the reservations submitted by the Spanish Delegation at the Geneva Assembly, the procedure suggested is not regarded by the Government as being the most suited io achieve the required end: for the Budget does not exactly reflect the armed strength of a State, since it may be necessary to increase the credits allotted to the Ministry of War and to the Admiralty in order to maintain that strength at its present level.Moreover, my Government has to take into consideration the fact that a reduction of military expenditure could hardly take place unless some common procedure is agreed upon by all Powers, a condition which is not fulfilled in the present case.I have the honour to be, etc.(Signed) QUINONES DE LEON.The Hon. Sir Eric Drummond, K.C.M.G., C.B., Secretary-General of the League of Nations, Geneva.REPLY OF THE GREEK GOVERNMENT.[Translation.']Greek Permanent Secretariat to the League of Nations.No. 681. Geneva, June 21th, 1921.Sir,In reply to your letter of March 8th, 1921 (21/31/27), with regard to the limitation of military expenditure, I have the honour to inform you, by order of my Government, that, despite its keen desire to participate in the gradual reduction of armaments, it is impossible for it at the present, moment to conform to the Recommendation adopted by the Assembly of the League of Nations at its meeting of December 14th, 1920, and to take up this question owing to the state of war which at present exists with Turkey, the responsibility for which certainly does not fall upon Greece.I am, etc.(Signed) V. DENDRAMIS, The Director of the Greek Permanent Secretarial.To the Hon. Sir Eric Drummond,Secretary-General of the League of Nations, Geneva. W. 1., le 20 juin 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,Comme suite a votre lettre en date du 8 mars sur la reduction des defenses pour les armements, j'ai 1'honneur de vous informer que le Gouver-nement de Sa Majesty a ete prie", par le Gouvernement de la Nouvelle-Zelande, de vouloir bien vous faire savoir que la Nouvelle-Zelande se interalliees entierement aux vues exposees dans la lettre que je vous ai adressee en date du 2 juin, sous le n0 38/1/3.Veuillez agreer, etc.(Signe) ARTHUR JAMES BALFOUR.A 1'HonorableSir Eric Drummond, K.C.M.G., C.B., Societe des Nations, Geneve.REPONSE DU GOUVERNEMENT ROUMAIN.Delegation du Royaume de Roumanie a la Societe des Nations.Le ler juin 1921.Monsieur le Secretaire General,En reponse a votre note portant le n0 21/31/27 du 8 mars dernier. j'ai 1'honneur de vous faire connaitre que le Gouvernement roumain, convaincu de la necessite de reduire les armements, a pris avec satisfaction connais-sance du vceu adopte le 14 decembre 1920 par PAssemblee de la Societe des Nations.Le budget propose pour l'exercice 1921/1922 est au-dessous du chiffre global des depenses militaires de 1'exercice 1920/1921. Toutefois, le Gouverne-ment roumain, de par la situation geographique du pays, se trouve dans la necessite d'etre tres reserve sur cette question. Autant que tout autre, il desire eviter la guerre, mais il ne peut etre certain de n'etre jamais amene dans la dure necessite de se defendre.Veuillez agr^er, etc.Le Directeur du Secretariat permanent: (Signe) PH. LAHOVARY. REPLY OF THE GOVERNMENT OF NEW ZEALAND.Offices of the Cabinet, 38/1/3.Sir,2, Whitehall Gardens, London, S.W.I., June 207/*, 1921.With reference to your letter dated March 8th on the subject of the limitation of expenditure on armaments, I have to inform you that His Majesty's Government have been requested by the Government of New Zealand to acquaint you that they wish to associate themselves with the views contained in my letter to you No. 38/1/3 of June 2nd.I am, etc.,(Signed) ARTHUR JAMES BALFOUR.The Hon. Sir Eric Drummond, K.C.M.G., C.B., League of Nations, Geneva.REPLY OF THE ROUMANIAN GOVERNMENT.[Translation.]Roumanian Delegation to the League of Nations.June 1st, 1921.Sir,In reply to your letter No. 21/31/27 of March 8th last, I have the honour to inform you that the Roumanian Government is convinced of the necessity of reducing armaments, and that it has accordingly learned with satisfaction of the Recommendation adopted by the Assembly of the League of Nations on December 14th last.The estimates for the financial year 1921/1922 are smaller than the total of military expenditure for the financial year 1920/1921. Nevertheless, owing to the geographical situation of the country, the Roumanian Government feels compelled to maintain considerable reserve on this question. It desires as sincerely as any other Government to avoid war, but it cannot be certain that it will never be faced with the stern necessity of defending itself.(Signed) PH. LAHOVARY, Director of the Permanent Secretarial,To the Secretary-General, League of Nations, Geneva.
